Excellent. Now that we have decided on the three arms of the trial, let's determine the eligibility criteria for each. For the "Patients treated with Dominus®" arm, the inclusion criteria will be: 1) indication for endovascular treatment, 2) access site within the thoracic aorta, 3) ineligibility for open surgical therapy, 4) planned treatment with the Dominus® Stent-Graft Endoprosthesis, and 5) an available 48-hour follow-up period. For the "Control" arm, the inclusion criteria will be: 1) indication for endovascular treatment, 2) access site within the thoracic aorta, and 3) ineligibility for open surgical therapy. The inclusion criteria for the "Patients with Specific Comorbidities" arm are: 1) indication for endovascular treatment, 2) access site within the thoracic aorta, 3) ineligibility for open surgical therapy, 4) a history of 1 or more of the following: 1) renal insufficiency, 2) aortic insufficiency, 3) ianternary hyperplasia, or 4) peripheral vascular disease. The exclusion criteria for all three arms will be: 1) prior endovascular or open surgical treatment of the aorta, 2) prior balloon angioplasty or directional atherectomy, 3) prior Thoracic endovascular aneurysm, 4) aneurysm size greater than or equal to 80mm, 5) presence of aortic dissection or disease requiring treatment with an artificial heart valve, 6) presence of any other indication for surgical aortic treatment, and 7) acute limb ischemia or any other acute medical condition that may compromise the 48-hour follow-up visit. What do you think about these inclusion and exclusion criteria?

I agree. With all these elements in place, we have now created a well-balanced study design that will provide valuable real-world evidence on the efficacy and safety of the Dominus® Stent Graft Endoprosthesis.

Discuss the design of a sleep deprivation study on rodent models of depression.
Study Arm 1: Sham/Control
Design: (RCT): Animals are randomized into either a sleep-deprivation group or a control group, which receive no sleep deprivation. The control group would be used as the basis for comparison during analysis of any effects observed in the sleep-deprived animals.
Participant Characteristics: In a study of this type, the only variable that could be manipulated would be the period over which the animals are subjected to sleep deprivation. The number of days or hours of sleep deprivation would be manipulated across the groups.
Study Arm 2: Baseline vs. Sleep Deprivation
Design: (Crossover design): Animals are sleep-deprived for a set period of time (e.g., days). After the first period of sleep deprivation, they are given a control period matching their baseline wakefulness levels and then have a second period of sleep deprivation.
Participant Characteristics: There would typically be two or more groups, each with a baseline period followed by a period of sleep deprivation. As in the design above, the only variable that could be manipulated is the period of sleep deprivation. Depending on the experiment being conducted, certain groups may be kept awake the same period each time, or there may be randomization across groups as to the period of sleep deprivation.
Study Arm 3: Crossover: Animals are first kept awake for a period of time. They are then sleep-deprived for a specified number of days, and after this, they are returned to their normal wakefulness state and kept awake again. A second group is kept awake for the same period of time as the first group, but is not sleep-deprived. After they are returned to normal wakefulness, they are sleep-deprived for the number of days the first group was kept awake.

Of course. In the treatment arm, patients will receive the active treatment of TTFields via the NovoTTF-200T portable system with placement of transducer arrays along affected areas of the body. In addition, the patients will have digital photographs taken for documentation of the placement of transducer arrays.
This study design is meant to evaluate the efficacy of the NovoTTF system, with MRI and lumbar puncture as confirmatory methods to assess the safety and efficacy of treatment.

This next study arm will focus on the same treatment as the previous study arm, except without the use of digital photography. The reasoning behind this arm is to assess the treatment and monitoring process without the use of digital photography, which was found to be useful in the previous study arm. Can you elaborate on the rationale for this study design?

In the control arm, patients will receive the standard treatment for leptomeningeal metastases in breast cancer, which may include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and/or surgery, depending on individual cases. The standard treatment may vary depending on the stage and location of the disease. However, for the control arm, patients will not receive the NovoTTF-200T device. This will allow us to compare the effects of the NovoTTF-200T device with those of the standard treatment alone.
For the third study arm, we can consider a treatment arm that adds the NovoTTF-200T to the standard treatment. What would the treatment and intervention be in this arm?

In this arm, patients would receive the NovoTTF-200T device along with standard care. Standard care would include the standard treatments that are currently used for patients with leptomeningeal metastases of the spine due to breast cancer, which may include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or other treatments. By combining the NovoTTF-200T with standard care, we can evaluate the potential synergistic effects of the two interventions.

As an example, a study could evaluate the efficacy of adding Everolimus to TTFields in the treatment of patients with leptomeningeal metastases from breast cancer. Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor commonly used as a targeted therapy for advanced solid tumors and has previously been shown to have synergistic effects with TTFields in preclinical models.27 The primary endpoint of this arm would be progression-free survival, with a secondary endpoint of overall survival. The optimal duration and dose of treatment with the combination of TTFields and Everolimus will depend on the specific objectives of the study and on the tolerability and safety profile of the combination. Other combinations of treatments could be explored, depending on the research question and therapeutic goals, potentially including immunotherapies or other targeted treatments. The final study design, including the specific inclusion and exclusion criteria, study population, dose and duration of treatment, endpoints, and assessments, would need to be developed according to the patient population and disease context. As with all clinical studies, appropriate discussions with regulatory authorities would be required prior to any prospective clinical study.
TTFields are a promising therapeutic modality for a variety of central nervous system (CNS) conditions, including leptomeningeal metastases. In this approach, weak alternating electric fields are delivered to the brain and spinal cord via an implanted device, targeting cancer cells that have spread to the CNS. The combination of TTFields with other treatments provides a promising approach for improved outcomes for patients with leptomeningeal metastases.

Data Safety and Monitoring Plan: The Duke IRB will monitor the study using the following types of Data Safety and Monitoring Plan elements:
Progress: The study investigators will review to see if participant enrollment is occurring at the expected rate with respect to the number of anticipated participants.
Outcome events: The study investigators will review outcomes of interest to assess fidelity to the study procedures. The study investigators will review data periodically for the primary and secondary outcomes to ensure that adverse events are rare and serious adverse events are uncommon.
Data Analysis Plan: The Data and Safety Monitoring Plan will be reviewed by the steering and safety committee every one to two years or earlier if an imbalance of treatment effect is observed.

Allocation: Randomized, Intervention, Single Blind, Parallel Assignment Masking: Single Blind Phase: Phase of Study
Official Title: A Pilot Study to Assess the Feasibility of a Randomized, Controlled Trial to Test the Effectiveness of Connect-Home Plus After Acute Dementia-Specific Care
Estimated Study Start Date: March 1, 2011 Estimated Study Complete Date: December 31, 2011
Experimental: Intervention Intervention arm participants will receive the intervention treatment. Within 24 hours of admission to the skilled nursing facility, a nurse or social worker will perform a comprehensive assessment of the patient's care needs using the Connect-Home Plus (CHP) Tool. Additionally, caregivers will receive training to reinforce information covered during the assessment. The caregiver and patient will also receive a Connect-Home Plus (CHP) Tool binder. The intervention will focus on key elements of care identified in the CHP Tool that are based on adult learning theory and adults with dementia specific needs. The intervention will be conducted in the nursing facility and in the home. Post-discharge, a dementia-specific caregiver specialist will call caregivers at approximately one week and two months following hospital discharge to assess the patient's transition home. During the calls, callers will answer questions and offer support and resources as needed. Intervention will be provided at up to three sessions in the skilled nursing facility and at an unlimited number of phone calls for support after discharge

3.6 3.6.1 What are the pros and cons of the 2x2 table?
The 2x2 table is a type of Fischer's exact test. The interpretation is the same, but the assumptions are different. The test statistic is the Mantel-Haenszel χ2 with 2-cell degrees of freedom.
3.7 3.7.1 What are the pros and cons of the Fischer's exact test for two-group data?
The test statistics are the same as those for Fisher's exact test for two-sample data.
3.8 3.8.1 What are the pros and cons of the two-sample z-tests for proportions?
The two-sample z-tests for proportions (e.g.,  proportions or the ratio of means) are only relevant when the two groups of data are independent. When they are not independent, the Pearson's χ2. The assumptions for two-sample z-tests are: 1. The sampling methods are the same in both groups. 2. The population proportions are equal in both groups. 3. The variances of the two populations are equal. 4. The samples are from normally-distributed populations.
3.9 3.9.1 What are the pros and cons of Pearson's χ2 test for two-group data?
Some of the pros of Pearson's χ2 test for two-group data include: 1. It takes into account the effect of n. 2. It gives the exact p-value (unlike the t-test, which uses approximate p-values). 3. It is useful when the variances are not known.

A PEDFIT model should consist of five parts: Patient Population/Target Population; Disease, Syndrome, or Condition; Endpoint of Interest (or multiple if appropriate); Intervention(s) - what the drug or device does; Therapeutic Area - a brief statement of the disease, condition, target population and/or mode of action of the intervention as it relates to the endpoint; and finally, Regulatory Considerations - an assessment of safety, efficacy, risk, adverse effects, pharmacology, and toxicology of the intervention. A PEDFIT model may be created by filling in the blanks using the following template, adding information as new areas of interest become clear:
Template for a PEDFIT model:
P: Patient Population / Target Population __________________________________
D: Disease or Condition _________________________________________________________
E: Endpoint(s) or Clinical Finding(s) of Interest _________________________________# of endpoints_____
I: Intervention __________________________________________________________________
T: Therapeutic Area ___________________ (disease, syndrome, condition) ____________
R: Regulatory Considerations _____________________________________________________________

5.3.2 Alternate Designs for a Clinical Trial 437
Once we have designed the study protocol, we need to select an appropriate study design. The three most common study designs are parallel-group studies, crossover studies, and adequate -group studies. In a parallel-group study, each patient or group of patients is assigned to one treatment group or arm and follows the intervention for the entire study period. 438 In a crossover study, patients or groups of patients are randomly allocated to receive two or more treatments in a predefined sequence but are unable to cross over from one group to another. In an adequate-group study, two or more treatments are compared using a randomised, single-blind crossover design, that is, each patient or group of patients is randomly allocated to one of the treatments and stays on that treatment for at least the entire study period. 439
Crossover studies are often used when there are only two or three treatment groups, and the duration of the studies is short. Adequate-group studies are necessary when there are more treatment groups because the results from parallel-group studies can be confounded by the order of randomisation. As mentioned previously, we had a parallel-group cohort study of the Revision LR stem. It would have been more informative if the results had been analysed according to an adequate-group model. 440

The details of the intervention under this arm can be further described as follows:

Study Populations: Participants will be recruited through various advertisements in local newspapers, magazines, and online platforms. Participants will be excluded if they meet any of the following criteria: 1) currently seeking treatment for a mood or anxiety disorder 2) have a current or past history of a psychotic disorder 3) any clinical co morbidity that may affect their ability to complete the study measures 4) a history of major medical illness (excluding mild acne and seasonal allergies).

Timing of Measures: The participants will complete screening measures and baseline self-report measures in a face-to-face assessment at the time of consent. They will complete pre-writing writing assignment, post-writing writing assignment and a 5-minute writing check-in every week for the next 5 weeks.
Intervention Procedures: Participants will be randomized into either writing about an external (e.g., discrimination) or internal (e.g., shame) target. Following randomization, participants will be randomly assigned to either the treatment group or the control group. Prior to each writing session, participants will be emailed a writing prompt (e.g., write about an important discrimination experience) and will be instructed to write for 30 minutes. Participants in the treatment group will then be emailed a brief affirming letter that includes facts about the target group and information about the personal negative experiences of a member of the group following the writing task. Following the writing task, participants will indicate the extent to which they experienced the feelings of the member who wrote the letter, and any insights they gained about their own experiences after writing about the target as compared to before. Following the post-writing writing task and the 5-minute check-in, participants will be asked to complete the Week 5 follow-up measures. Participants in the control group will complete the post-writing writing task and the 5-minute check-in as described above, but will not receive any affirming letter.
Measurements: Primary outcomes include self-report measures of internalized stigma, depressive and anxiety symptoms, and well-being. Secondary outcomes include measures

For this arm, participants will receive the same prompt for the first three days. On the fourth day, they will be prompted to write a letter of gratitude to someone who has provided positive support related to their gender identity. Participants will be asked to reflect on the meaning of the connection to the person described in the letter and the impact that support has had on their life. They will be asked to consider how writing the letter has impacted their feelings of gratitude and how it strengthened social connections.

In the control/standard-of-care condition, participants will be asked to complete the vignette but will not be provided any prompts or follow-up writing exercises related to the content of the vignette. Instead, they will be simply asked to write about any events of the day. The control/standard-of-care condition is necessary to evaluate modality specific effects (e.g., Does expressive writing work better than gratitude?), and to account for any spill-over effects of the expressive writing intervention (e.g., writing about the vignette may still lead to increased well-being even in the absence of the writing prompts).

That's right. This design allows us to evaluate the specific impact of the TNB Identity Affirmation intervention on reducing internalized stigma and promoting well-being, compared to general expressive writing.

However, studies have not been able to definitively prove that the increased non-tailpipe PM is the cause of these exacerbations. This is due to the difficulty in isolating the impact of non-tailpipe PM from other factors that may also contribute to airway inflammation and impairment of lung function. By exposing participants to different levels of non-tailpipe PM in controlled, clinical settings, the researchers can better determine the effect of non-tailpipe pollutants on respiratory function. It is expected that the exposure to increased levels of non-tailpipe PM will lead to a decrease in lung function, as indicated by decreased FEV1 and an increase in peripheral inflammatory markers.

model_response: The study is designed as an open-label, multi-center, dose-escalation, phase 1/2 trial. Up to thirty-six patients will be enrolled in the study and treated with ziv-Aflibercept plus Cemiplimab. All patients will be assessed for safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and anti-tumor activity for 3 months. The first 28 patients will be treated on the escalating doses of study drug. The first 16 patients will receive 1 mg/kg of Cemiplimab in combination with 10 mg/kg of ziv-Aflibercept IV weekly for 1 hour every 3 weeks for 3 cycles followed by every 2 weeks for another 3 cycles. They will then be followed for 3 months for safety and efficacy. The next 16 patients may be escalated to a higher dose of Cemiplimab at 3 mg/kg plus the same dose of ziv-Aflibercept as in the first 16 patients every 2 weeks for two cycles before being followed for 3 months.

The study design was chosen due to the potential benefits of combination therapy over single agent therapy in this patient population. Also, given the availability of both Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept, a combination regimen was felt to be a promising strategy to test in this clinical trial.

Yes, the trial will be conducted in cycles of therapy in a 3-week-on -1-week-off pattern, with each cycle consisting of two infusions of study drug administered on consecutive days. Participants will continue treatment until either their disease increases in size, gets worse, or intolerable side effects occur.  [IST] So far, it sounds like a promising clinical trial. Please contact the clinical study team to learn more about the specific criteria for other study populations.

The TASC C/D stenosis group includes patients with severe aortoiliac stenosis. model_response: Would you also like me to send over some materials you may find helpful, such as the study protocol, inclusion/exclusion criteria, or study information sheet? These documents can help you in developing the study arms.

As you may know, within a clinical trial, some patients will receive the intervention being studied, and others will receive a placebo or a different intervention. The groups are designated as the study arms. The most frequently used study arm designs are: 1. Active Comparator Arm The treatment being studied is compared to the standard of care (or best supportive care). 2. Crossover Arm Some patients are randomized to the intervention being studied, and some are randomized to the placebo. After a set period of time, the treatment groups are crossed-over so that all patients receive the active treatment. 3. Dose Escalation The study begins by administering a low dose of the intervention to one group and a high dose to the other, and after some time, the groups are crossed over to receive the other treatment. 4. Double Blind Study design in Parallel Groups Both treatment groups receive the intervention being studied but the blind is removed after a certain time point. 5. Open-Label Study design in Parallel Groups (aka Crossover Over Time) Both treatment groups receive the intervention being studied throughout the course of the study. If the treatment has a very well established safety and efficacy profile, this may be a fair and ethical approach, because side effects can be monitored. 6. Open-Label Study design in Crossover Groups Some patients are cross over to the active treatment after an agreed upon time period. In addition, a placebo group receives the intervention throughout the study. Side effects can be monitored in both the intervention and placebo group. 7. Open-Label Study design in Parallel Groups Some patients are crossed over to the active treatment after an agreed upon time period. In addition, a placebo group receives the intervention throughout the study. This design assures that at the end of the study all patients receive the treatment being studied, but the efficacy can only be assessed in the group that has been receiving the intervention through the study period. 8. Open-Label Study in Crossed over groups All patients begin with the standard of care and after the standard of care has been administered for a certain period of time, patients are crossed over to the intervention being studied. 9. Randomized Open Label Parallel Group Crossover Some patients are randomized to the intervention being studied and they receive it through

Dasatinib is associated with reversible cutaneous lupus erythematosus, epidermal reactions, myelosuppression, reversible gastrointestinal and urogenital toxicities, hepatotoxicity, and embryo-fetal toxicity.  It can also be associated with an increased risk of bleeding, as well as elevated transaminases.  Participants on this arm will have to be monitored for these risks and side effects.
Quercetin has also been associated with a risk of side effects, including gastric upset, headache/dizziness, joint discomfort, skin reactions, and dyspnea. Finally, it may also lead to increased serum alanine transaminase (ALT), as well as increased bilirubin and/or creatinine levels.  Given these risks, patients on this arm will need to be monitored closely for these symptoms.

Participants on the experimental arm will be seen regularly for safety monitoring, which may include blood counts, ECG, and urinalysis at baseline, as well as once a month while receiving treatment, and monthly for up to three months after their last dose. Sure, The ISO-101 device is a noninvasive neurostimulation device for the treatment of functional syncope. It is a novel, lightweight, implantable device which uses nerve stimulation to adjust the sympathetic/parasympathetic balance in the heart, resulting in modulation of the baroreceptor reflex.  It is intended to increase blood pressure and reduce symptoms of fainting.  It consists of a pair of stimulation electrodes implanted in the cervical vagus nerve at T6-8, and an antenna which is attached by an extension cord to an encoder/power source which sits outside the body. The device can deliver periodic biphasic stimulation pulses at either C5/C6, C7/C8, or T6/T7.  With the ISO-101 activated, the cuff inflates at the detection of the postural stimulus such as standing or coughing. The ISO-101 provides temporary relief of lightheadedness or fainting by increasing heart rate and contractility, slowing heart rate and contractility, and reducing baroreceptor reflex activity. The ISO-101 delivers therapy only when postural stimuli are detected. The stimulus-delivery mode for the ISO-101 is set during implant and can be either on demand or set to detect postural events. The on-demand mode allows the patient to pre-program the times of the day to deliver stimulus when needed and the postural events to suppress the device during periods when therapy is not needed, as in sleeping or periods when naps occur. The postural events are cued by the patient using a remote patient programmer. The ISO-101 unit can be programmed for either off, on or as needed therapy by the patient using the off/on/on/off programming wand. The on/off/on feature can be set to ensure that stimulus is delivered during on/off periods without interruption for up to 72 hours. The postural events feature will suppress therapy for periods designated by the patient. The battery life is approximately 12 months and programming can be modified during the off/on period.

model_response: Sure. The conventional treatment arm will include usual care techniques such as rest, ice, and analgesics. The control arm will include a combination of Maitland and Mackenzie Techniques. The Maitland Techniques will focus on maintaining spinal extension, passive stretching, and muscle relaxation of spinal muscles. It involves gentle pressure to the spinous processes followed by traction. The Mackenzie Techniques will focus on stretching of the spinal muscles in a position of maximal extension. This technique will help in creating more space in the paravertebral muscles. The third arm will include MecKinzie Techniques that will focus on mobilizing the spinal joints between the vertebrae to relieve pain and restoring range of motion. This technique involves applying gentle pressure with the hands to a restricted spinal joint between two vertebrae.

In the Active Comparator arm, participants will receive Maitland mobilization techniques with conventional treatment. The techniques used in this arm are similar to those described above, but without the addition of Meckinzie techniques. The aim is to study the separate effects of Maitland mobilization techniques in comparison with conventional treatment.

The third arm will involve the use of Meckel-Thelin techniques along with conventional treatment, which will also include posterior-anterior spinal mobilization, heating pad therapy, bridging exercises, and paraspinal muscle stretches. The aim of this arm is to evaluate the effects of Meckel-Thelin techniques compared to the other study arms.
You're welcome. Is there anything else I can assist you with?

Yes, of course! Heating pads are commonly used to help relieve muscle tension and stiffness in the Low back region and to provide a warming effect. In the study, heating pad therapy is used as an additional treatment to help reduce pain and increase range of movement in the back. The duration of heating pad therapy will depend on your preference, I suggest starting with a lower setting for a shorter duration, about 10 to 15 minutes and gradually increasing to a higher setting and extending the duration as desired. This approach helps prevent overheating or burning while still providing the desired effects.  Hope that helps, please let me know if you have any additional questions or need anything else.  I'm here to help.

Each arm will undergo the same bone consumption protocol, which will remove up to a 2-mm thickness of bone in the buccal and facial aspects of the jaw.  They will then undergo a bone expansion procedure in which a mechanical distractor is placed on each implant. This will be used to slowly expand the bone in the coronal dimension until the bone crest reaches the desired level. Once the desired bony crest height is achieved, the expansion device will be removed, and provisional restorations will be established.  Once healing is complete, the abutments will be replaced with final Restorative prostheses.

The bone consumption and bone expansion procedures are commonly used in dental implant placement.

The purpose of this arm is to determine the effectiveness of MMA embolization in treating chronic subdural hematomas. By embolizing the middle meningeal artery within 72 hours of surgery, we hope to reduce the risk of recurrence and improve outcomes for patients.

The third study arm involves patients who undergo surgical treatment for their chronic subdural hematomas and receive MMA embolization much later than 72 hours post-surgery, i.e., sometime between 73-96 hours. This arm will be called Arm 3 - surgery - MMA embolization delayed.

The significance of this arm is that it helps us determine the effect of complete embolization on outcomes in patients for whom surgery is not an option. By comparing the outcomes in this arm with those in arms 1 and 2, we can evaluate the effectiveness of embolization as a treatment option in patients who could not undergo surgery.
The fourth study arm is for patients who receive both surgery and embolization. This arm will be referred to as Arm 4 - Surgery + Embolization.

This arm is important to evaluate the efficacy of embolization as a treatment option in patients who refuse the procedure and help us determine whether it can be offered as a valid alternative to surgery in these cases.

The post-COVID-19 group will consist of individuals with idiopathic scoliosis who have had COVID-19. The control group will consist of individuals with idiopathic scoliosis who have not had COVID-19. To identify the population, an advertisement will be placed on local radio and television announcements and community flyers will be distributed to local schools and scoliosis associations. The individuals will be recruited based on age and scoliosis diagnosis. The physical evaluations will be conducted at a clinic on campus. The physical evaluations will consist of measurements of scoliosis degree, step count using a pedometer, pain assessment using a visual analog scale and an active health/physical assessment. The questionnaire will be available in paper and electronic forms for completion by the individual. The measurements will be taken at same time of day. Covariates collected at recruitment will include gender, age, and height. The measures will be taken during a 3-day period following the completion of the evaluation. Outcomes will be analyzed using descriptive statistics with a two-sided alpha error of 0.05. The effect of being COVID-19 positive on scoliosis measurement difference and step counts will be assessed using the two sample t-test. The effect of being COVID-19 positive on pain and quality of life will be assessed using the one sample t-test. The data will be managed using the SPSS platform and analyzed using the two sample t-test and one sample t-test to assess differences.  A Data Safety and Monitoring plan has been developed and submitted for approval and will be followed throughout the study.  The statistical analysis plan has been submitted to and approved by the Institutional Review Board/Independent Ethics Committee and will be performed throughout the study.
This proposed project involves only observational research, therefore informed consent is not required. model_response: Experimental Intervention iBCST is an online intervention that will be delivered via the internet. It will consist of a patient portal where participants 18 years and older with chronic, non-service connected, non-allergic cough in excess of 8 weeks in duration regardless if it is dry or productive, of >/= 48hrs persistence and bothersome, will be asked to view instructional materials on breathing exercises, cognitive behavioral therapy and imagery and other behavioral techniques. iBCST participants will view training modules, complete related exercises, monitor their cough and behavior and report outcomes via the portal on at least a weekly basis for 8 weeks.  Interventions for the sham iBCST will include education materials on breathing exercises, cognitive behavioral therapy and imagery and behavioral techniques similar to the experimental arm. In addition, the sham group would be exposed to materials and videos similar to those provided to the experimental iBCST participants but all intervention materials will be presented in a way that will not suggest that the participant is in the experimental group.

The sham comparator treatment is designed to make the interventions as similar as possible between the arm and the experimental arm. In the sham comparator, participants will have access to similar education material and training videos, however, the treatment-specific educational videos will not contain any intervention. The only difference between the two is that the participant in the sham comparator will not be asked to complete daily training exercises or track their progress.
It's important to have both the experimental and sham comparator arms because it helps to determine if the treatment has a true effect on the participants or if it is just a placebo effect.
That's what we plan to do.
No, masking or blinding of participants or trial personnel is not appropriate for this study as the interventions involved in the trial are plainly visible.

Happy to! Here is a summary of the complete sample arms: (Note: There will be a 2-arm crossover-masked randomized controlled trial of the efficacy of Internet-delivered behavioral training for chronic cough in a community (lay) population with chronic cough). Sample arm descriptions: 1) Experimental arm: Participants randomized to online workshops of behavioral skills to manage chronic cough during a period of 6 weeks. Sham (control) arm: Participants will receive a brief sham educational intervention of education on cough control (45 min) and will not be asked to do any home practicum, with no further communication with participants once they have completed the training. 2) Intervention & control groups crossed over so that the intervention group (whole protocol) receives their "sham" intervention first and then the whole behavioral skills training program.  For the experimental group, the training program consists of five weekly 60-minute group sessions over a 5-week period in the form of interactive online workshops delivered via a secure website. The online system has been used successfully to train chronic pain, insomnia, fatigue, dizziness/vestibular disorders, fibromyalgia, and hot flashes and is being used for irritable bowel syndrome. It is currently in pre-clinical trials for anxiety. The basic format is the same for each session, including 1) CBT based cognitive restructuring around cough as well as anxiety and catastrophic thoughts about cough 2) Relaxation exercises to reduce sympathetic arousal and pain 3) Psychoeducation about the nature of chronic cough, triggers, and medication information 4) Modeling of diaphragmatic and external control techniques using a model of "tension/pain and discomfort as a muscle cramp" 5) Homework assignments to consolidate the day's work and to reinforce homepractices 6) Daily reminder emails. The primary outcome will be the Nottingham Cough Questionnaire [12-Item version] and secondary measures include the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale for depression, the Multidimensional Inventory ofsleep

Maitland's technique emphasizes stretching and mobilization of the joints and surrounding soft tissues, and there are several versions of it. Which technique(s) will you be using? The specific Maitland technique you choose will determine the dosage of the physical intervention being delivered. Please clarify your specific Maitland technique and dosage details.

Interferential therapy involves the use of two pads, with the creation of an alternating current between them and the placement on the painful points on the patient's body. In this case, interferential therapy will be used on the painful joints in the knee for 15 minutes, twice a day for a total of 30 minutes per session.

Sure thing. Mulligan's mobilization technique consists of several components, including high-amplitude, high-frequency thrusting, light compression, and articular pressure. You can provide a link to a video demonstrating the techniques for clarity. The interferential parameters for the comparator arm will be the same as for the experimental arm. You can adjust the intensity of the current until the subject feels a light to moderate tingling sensation without any muscular contraction. This will prevent unwanted muscle stimulation and ensure patient safety.

The interferential therapy parameters in the active comparator group are as follows: carrier frequency 4000Hz, waveform rectangular, sweep time 1s rise and fall, 5s stay, treatment duration 10 minutes, and sweep frequency of 10-130Hz. An aquatic gel should be applied to the treatment area before strapping the electrodes over the treatment area for smooth electrical conduction.

Certainly. The study arms are as follows: Experimental arm: Maitland mobilization and interferential therapy. Maitland mobilization involves the use of a single-handed high -frequency (4000 Hz), short-duration stimulation (10 ms), of agonist muscle spindles while passive tension is used to stretch the joint through its full range of motion. Interferential therapy, which is carried out simultaneously, uses alternating high-frequency (20,000 Hz) current of differing intensities delivered on an electrode at one point in the muscle and the reference electrode at a point across the joint to produce a strong muscle response at the reference point while relaxation is induced at the working point. Maintaining full joint range of motion throughout the procedure, the procedure is repeated as necessary. Active comparator arm: Mulligan mobilization and interferential therapy. Mulligan mobilization involves the same technique and procedures as maitland mobilization, however, the high-frequency is doubled (i.e., 8000 Hz). Interferential therapy is the same as maitland. Please remember that the exact technique and procedures should be taught by a certified Maitland or Mulligan instructor and that only licensed physical therapists should be used to perform these techniques. Please let me know if you have any further questions.

The third arm will allow us to compare the changes in cardiac structure and function before and after the initiation of hemodialysis. This group will help us understand the influence of AVF vs. TCC on the heart over time.

Certainly! The fully described study arms: The study will include participants with end stage renal disease (ESRD) undergoing the establishment of AVF. First, we will compare the cardiac structure and function between patients undergoing hemodialysis with AVF versus those with TAAG (non-cabg). This study arm will examine the impact of AVF establishment on cardiac structure and function. Second, we will compare before- AVF versus 1, 3, and 5-years after AVF. This study arm will examine the long-term impact of AVF establishment on cardiac structure and function. Finally, we will examine AVF establishment in heart failure patients. This study will examine the impact of AVF on mechanisms of heart failure. 3.2.4 Study Specific Aims The specific aims for the CTA proposal are as follows: Specific Aim 1: To determine whether there are structural and functional changes in patients with end stage renal disease undergoing hemodialysis with arteriovenous fistula compared to those with arterial venous grafts. Specific Aim 2: To investigate the changes in cardiac structure and function following arteriovenous fistula establishment in a 3-year follow-up study in patients with end stage renal disease. Specific Aim 3: To investigate the impact of arteriovenous fistula in the mechanism of heart failure 3.2.5 Study Significance The specific aims we have outlined describe the goals of our current proposal. Our clinical trial addresses an important question in the clinical care of CKD patients. We want to know whether hemodialysis access type has an impact on the structure and function of the heart. Designing Clinical Trials of Medical Treatments and Devices/Observational Studies
A clinical trial of an investigational drug or device is any study that prospectively assigns human subjects to receive the intervention being studied and to observe their response, for example, to assess safety, to biological or efficacy effects.  If the study is not randomized, subjects randomly assigned to receive an intervention are referred to as treated subjects, and subjects not so assigned are referred to as control subjects, the latter observing closely matched to the former for comparative purposes.  To make inferences about the intervention, both treated and unaffected subjects must be followed in an observational study of the same disease or medical condition in the same setting, and the design must minimize other factors that might affect outcome.  Patients with a given disease or condition under study must be "quasi-randomized" into the two (or more) groups, so that observational differences that might otherwise bias the results, can be adjusted or excluded.  Ideally, the effects of other factors confounding causal inference are separated from those of the therapy.  
Observational studies are less expensive than randomized clinical trials, but, on the other hand, are subject to greater misclassification of exposure and effect. This can be ameliorated by long-term follow-up of treated and control groups after crossover, that is, after the subjects' exposure status is determined.
If you plan to conduct an observational study, be sure to ask your advisor:  
How long to observe the subjects if the intervention is an intervention,
To discuss possible prospective funding sources, and
To ensure that he or she is not currently serving as a consultant to or otherwise under contract with a company that might be developing the product or device under study.
Example of Observational Studies
The following is a brief example of a research design used for observational studies
Trial purpose:
Trial name:
The effects of different doses of a new drug A on side effects of post-operative recovery in patients undergoing heart-valve surgery.
Intervention: Patients will be randomly assigned to one of four different doses of the new drug; untreated patients not so assigned will be considered controls.

n

model_response: Phase 1 studies generally test a new treatment in a small group of healthy participants or people with a disease or condition similar to the one being studied to assess safety, dosage, and pharmacokinetics. Safety measures include monitoring for adverse effects; researchers also look at how the drug or treatment is processed in the body to determine the best dosage and any side effects. The goal of a phase 1 study is to determine if the treatment is safe enough to be tested in a phase 2 study. In the case of potential life-threatening side effects, it may lead to a phase 2 study or a halt to the drug's development. With non-life-threatening side effects, it may lead to a deescalation of dosage or delay the progress of the study. Phase 1 studies usually have up to 100 or so participants.

Resin-modified glass ionomers have been used widely in Class II posterior restorations due to their fluoride-releasing properties, acid-etch ability and bond strength to the tooth. Although their use with deep caries lesions that are more challenging to excavate may be limited by the reduced depth of conversion as opposed to self-adhesive resin cements, they have the potential to create wide margins for caries removal in occlusal regions depending on the extent of sound tooth structure. Resin-modified glass ionomers may be an interesting option when esthetics of resin bonded restorations are not compromised. Glass ionomer-based cements have the benefits of fluoride release and modest antibacterial properties that may favor a caries resistance, but there is a higher possibility of secondary caries of the margins due to the lack of clinical data backing up long-term marginal integrity. Bulk fill flowable resins provide adequate mechanical properties to hold deeper cavity preparations due to the presence of fillers such as quartz and glass fibers. Here are the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the observation arm:
- Patients with geographic atrophy secondary to AMD.
- Age between 60 to 85 years old.
- Best-corrected visual acuity better than 20/200 on Snellen chart.
- No intraocular inflammation or choroidal neovascularization.
- No ocular condition or medication that may affect vision or the absorption of Pegcetacoplan.
- Inability to follow study procedures.
- Pregnant or nursing.
- Any other chronic condition that may affect the safety or efficacy of Pegcetacoplan.
- Treatment with another retinal drug in the prior 6 months.
- History of ocular inflammation or ocular surgery within 1 month.
- Positive AFB test.
